comments.commentBody:
I'm laughing myself (sic again).

It's been a long time waiting for a follow-up on the Zambesi zebra sleeping vertically on its horn (details on this may be fuzzy)
I'd be ok if that were your permanent avatar.

That's interesting -- do you think the aversion to photography back then was in the culture?, because I remember going to Europe with my mother in 1972 and insisting that I wouldn't take any photos, that I didn't want to be distracted from the experience of a place by thinking about what pictures to take, and that we would buy guidebooks if we wanted pictures.
I agree completely.  No excuses for another war. Let people decide for themselves what they want.

Richard, even with sharing your concerns and anxieties on the 9/11 catastrophe, I personally feel US better avoid another military involvement abroad, that too in Muslim Arab nation. As for the al-Qaida, already they are on run and under Drone fire at various places. Don't you think your domestic development priorities should receive more attention than wars or more than warranted defense spending?

Professor, arming secular rebels is not a distraction anywhere near as intense to our needs to rebuild our prosperity as invading Iraq and Afghanistan, then seeking for a decade to transform those nations into reflections of ourselves -- hopeless ambitions. Nobody is suggesting that we do that again within the lifetimes of any adult now living.

To accept your caution undiluted is for the U.S. to withdraw from the world entirely, and leave it, as our adversaries desire, to their own strident interventionist and hegemonic ambitions.

To wish an outcome in Syria that aligns with western interests (and in the Syrians' interests, as well); indeed, outcomes throughout Arab Spring countries; is perfectly rational and should have been achievable but for our decidedly disengaged approach to the region for the past four years, with the sole exception of surges in Afghanistan.

As to Qaeda being on the run and at the mercy of drone strikes, this very editorial calls that observation into question: they're in Syria, they're very much a going concern, and they may win. What is the likelihood that such a victorious force would entertain relations with the west? Isn't it more likely that they would foment regional destabilization in the hopes of gaining yet further ground for Islamist fundamentalism? And how, precisely, would such a likely outcome help India?

As reported earlier that the US was all prepared to intervene and militarily back some rebel groups in Syria It's still time for the US and its Western allies to have second thoughts on it. For, wouldn't it be premature on their part, rather rash to plunge into a quagmire, that the current Middle East turmoil does present, that too without ascertaining the credentials of an ally, the US wants to support against Bashar-al Assad's state repression and civilian bloodbath? While the US political/ diplomatic/ moral support to the Arab democratic upsurge could be understandable, as it represented a right shift in the US Middle East policy. Nonetheless thinking of direct military intervention through arming rebels, or contemplating forced regime change in various Arab nations would not only be a repetition of past follies, but self-ruinous too, specially when the internal situation of the US itself demands a focused attention to economic revival and national renewal through major developmental effort. Isn't it time to learn a lesson from Afghanistan, Iraq, or Libya? Better the US prepares itself to work in tandem with the international community and the UN, adopt wait-and watch approach on the Middle East developments, and help facilitate democratic transition there through diplomatic pressure and soft power projection, rather resurrect the al-Qaida, it fought against for full one decade.

such very sad news my condolences to the family and children , as an aspiring singer  and singing norteno and banda and mariachi , I could somewhat relate to her turmoils with the music industry and trying to raise a family and trying to stay married and raise a family . i can only hope  and pray that god can give the family peace in their hearts and in their  minds so that they may find closure soon . Again my deepest repescts .

On a more serious note, though, there is good oversharing that the internet has facilitated. The internet has opened up a whole world of support groups for a variety of people in need. I've been active in parenting communities for children with Autism and related disorders for twelve years. I've learned a lot from my fellow parents and received a lot of strength from their support. In pre-internet days, discounting much changed attitudes toward certain types of disorders, I would never have been able to find equivalent support.
They won't (Will et al) let him join in reideer games until one foggy Christmas Eve.

St. Nicholas Day is on December 6th. The puzzle is five days late.

ONEIDA! and ONEIN! on, ESTHETES! on, ANISE!
HANGON to your PILSENER, don't fall on your ESSAYs!

Did anyone notice that both MOM and DAD were also present?

DONDER is correct. Here is one of the original handwritten copies remaining, attributed to Clement Clarke Moore:

http://tinyurl.com/ckhk9ql

PS.
Since when does a VIXEN have antlers? And where is Rudy?

You are correct; moreover one cover the other "to protect global financial stability".
Behind, as you say, illegal action{s} for democracy etc etc

Just to clarify, HSBC was illegally laundering $7 billion into the United States on behalf of Mexican drug lords and the government settles for $1.5 billion in fines since criminal prosecution could threaten a too-big-to-fail bank with yet another global banking system collapse?

Innocent bystanders have been brutally killed on a daily basis as a result of the Mexican drug wars in the most deplorable condition possible. Families could've been spared the loss of their loved ones if funding wasn't available for the weaponry to kill such people. Every executive at HSBC who complied with this should be put behind bars for allowing this!

As a U.S. Citizen, I am utterly embarassed by a justice system that spares a bank of blatant criminal wrongdoing due to such a fallout bringing potential global financial stress. The Mexican drug wars continue on and the HSBC employees at the bottom of the rung in Buffalo will be added on to our unemployment roles once the bank vacates that building, but our global financial system will be just fine!

This is a major disappointment and blow to our economic system, credibility and integrity.  It allows Wall Street to continue on its spree of corruption and criminal activities unabated.  The financial industry will just factor in criminal penaties to the cost of doing business, and to make up for that additional cost it will charge customers higher fees and lay off more employees.  What happen to our nation of laws?  I think Congress (God help us) should appeal this decision on behalf of The People.  We should all write to our Representatives and Senators!
Both of your comments reminded me of Paul Simon's "Don't take my Kodachrome away." It came out in 1973. You two might be onto something here. I too traveled a lot back then and did not take pictures.

This is an incredible breakthrough and one of many for which we need a voice on the National Cancer Institute's board. Please sign the online petition to get a pediatric oncologist appointed to the NCI board. Our kids need a voice. Thank you. Here is a more direct link to the petition so it involves one less click:

https://petitions.whitehouse.gov/petition/appoint-pediatric-oncologist-n...
'

Your conclusion is correct, but your reasoning all wrong. As late as the mid '80s boxing was thriving with Hagler, Hearns, Leonard et. al. What killed it was not the violence of it, that had been around 100 years. What killed it was the thuggery of the participants...the outside of the ring persona and criminality of guys like Tyson and Spinks. Those with money stopped supporting the beast.

The same will happen with football. Not because the spectators will grow tired of the violence on the field. But rather the violence on the field will ensure that the sponsors will not let their kids play. The next generation of ticket buyers will grow up having never played the game, and not knowing anyone who did. The chain will be broken, the passion sapped.

There is no reason the helmet needs to be a hard shell. Football is incredibly adaptable. I would bet on a complete redesign of the pads. Once upon a time football was determined to be killing too many young men. In response the forward pass was added to spread the game out. Football will survive but it must adapt.

Doing away with the inheritance tax means that the societal unit of wealth is the multigenerational family rather than the individual -- Rockefeller rather than John D. or Nelson or Jay.  We go back to aristocracy.
Evidently neither Ms. Block, or Mr. Chase either.
Edwin Drood is a "starless revival"?  If Chita Rivera isn't a legitimate Broadway star who is?

"Go! DONNER, On! MABEL and VIXEN, Now! DASHER, Now! DANCER, Stop Looking!"

Howie

Reply to Cathleen

The Washington elite live in a bubble. A bubble that so distorts their view of reality, that to those outside that bubble they appear stupid and dishonest. And some of them are no doubt just stupid and dishonest.
Your comment is both misogynist and racist. This is not a big news story - because the woman was Indian?

``...morals out the window.'' ``... it still seems pretty tawdry.''

The woman would be living today if proper she received proper medical treatment. Who according to you threw the morals out the window?
How does gay marriage violate or otherwise affect your religious liberty?

We dont know how we work. These discoveries will be part of theories that explain and predict them some day, and this knowledge will open up the possibility of freeing ourselves from these influences to an extent, by knowing they are operating and taking measures to counterbalance them.

We free ourselves from, for example, always having to have the last word by recognizing the pattern and biting our tongues as necessary. In this way we can become freer; this is human freedom in development and has little to do with free will.

Not sure I've seen anyone deny that football is a tough sport.  The issue seems to be that league knew the impact that multiple head injuries have in the long term.  That they knew former players were suffering from dementia and brain disorders at ages far lower than the general population and kept that knowledge to themselves.  If you find that to be an acceptable business practice then I pray for your cold heart and soul.

Jen D is right.  But we also should end the expense to schools and the damage to the bodies of student athletes caused by intercollegiate athletics.  Intramural touch football in which all students are encouraged to play makes more sense.
criminal child abuse.  Jail time for parents who permit it. A vanity run wild.  Flag rugby is the game for all mankind!

Parents should not allow their kid to play football because of possible brain injuries.

However, the decision will probably be made on monetary grounds.
